name: Consul Democracy
description: Consul Democracy is the most complete citizen participation tool for an open, transparent and democratic government. This tool is free, secure, open-source and easy to use, reflecting public values at its core, so that all governments can take the first steps toward digital citizen participation.

sdgs.sdg: SDG16: Peace¸ Justice and Strong Institutions
sdgs.relevance:
Consul Democracy is used by governments globally on local, regional and national level to involve citizens in decision-making, helping to both develop effective, accountable and transparent institutions as well as ensuring responsive, inclusive, participatory and representative decision-making at all levels. Transparency and accountability is further enhanced thanks to the open-source nature of Consul's development, which is community based. More on the goals, the way we work and participating institutions can be read on: https://consulfoundation.org/about and https://consulproject.org/

Moreover, we support governments to work on all Sustainable Development Goals with their citizens. We have joined forces with The United Nations Development Programme and the cooperative Enreda to foster participation around the Agenda 2030 by incorporating a SDG module into the software, so that entities around the world can use it in their Sustainable Development Goals localization processes.

protectionFromHarassment.harassmentPolicy:
Consul Democracy includes a moderation interface that allows the public workers administrating the platform to ensure that the platform remains a safe space:

The administrators can hide or delete any content and block users

Any user can flag any content of the platform (comments, proposals, debates, projects, etc) as inappropriate leading to an alert in the moderation system

In case the government wants to establish a more advanced moderation system, Consul allows creating users with the specific role of moderators, allowing trusted parties or specialists in the matter to carry out the task. 
Any actions performed by the moderators are also tracked in the administrators' interface to ensure that the process is done correctly and with all the guarantees.
(see e.g. sections 1.9 and 2.0 of the administration guide https://consulproject.org/docs/consul_administration_guide_en.pdf)

Regarding the age of the users, Consul allows connecting the platform to the verification system of the government to verify each user before using the platform and prevent access by underage users. (see e.g. https://docs.consulproject.org/docs/english-documentation/features/census_configuration and an example of Conditions of use of a city explaining that it is not allowed the use of the platform by underage users https://decide.madrid.es/conditions)

privacy.privacyCompliance:
The whole Consul Democracy software is licensed through a AGPL-3.0 license https://www.gnu.org/licenses/agpl-3.0.en.html One of the most common open source license used worldwide.

Consul is a standalone platform that does not need any personal data to be used. Each government using Consul Democracy defines in each case if they want to collect data from the users, and if that is the case which conditions apply to the collection and protection of the data. Consul allows the government to publish all the terms and conditions that apply to their use of the platform as well as to require the users' consent to such conditions and to any collection and treatment of data that the government decides to do with the platform. Consul Democracy is not offered as SaaS but as software that each government has to install and administer by themselves. Thus each government is responsible for the servers running Consul, the data stored in them, the security of them, and applying any law relevant to the service they will be providing.
